column2: Average Class Size and Class Size Distribution (Elementary)\r2016-172016-172016-172016-172017-182017-182017-182017-182018-192018-192018-192018-19\rAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# of\rGrade\rClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*\rLevel\rSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSize\r1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+\rK\r24152315275\r\r1\r274274265\r\r2\r274265265\r\r3\r254274264\r\r4\r32133633413\r\r5\r363344373\r\r6\r281133243114\r\rOther**\r131121\r*Numbe r of classes indicates how many classes fall into each size category (a range of total students per class).\r** “Other” category is for multi-grade level classes.\r\r\rProfessional Development provided for Teachers\r\rMeasure2017-182018-192019-20\rNumber of school days dedicated to Staff Development and Continuous Improvement5 days5 days5 days\r\rProfessional development is ongoing to keep Dry Creek staff abreast of new learning strategies
column3: innovative teaching techniques and applied technology\rin the field of education. A weekly planning opportunity is provided for teachers to coordinate and plan lessons or units as an entire grade level.\r\rDry Creek’s professional development currently focuses on improving our collective knowledge of curriculum and needed changes in instructional\rdelivery. Our third- through sixth-grade classes participated in the third statewide Smarter Balanced Assessment tests in the spring of 2019. The Dry\rCreek students performed well on the assessments in comparison to all schools in CUSD
column4: and this school year’s fourth- through sixth-grade teachers are\rusing the results to engage students in meaningful conversations about areas of strength and growth. As students become more familiar with this new\rrigorous assessment system
column5: we believe our students will rise to the challenge and demonstrate mastery of the California State Standards.\r\rTeachers new to the profession are sup-ported by a formal mentoring system
column6: which includes release time to observe lessons taught by veteran teachers.\rAll teachers are encouraged to participate in external professional improvement opportunities
column7: such as attendance at conferences and workshops.\r\rThe district focused all professional development activities around five identified needs:  first time best instruction
column10: implementation of the California Content Standards and NGSS Standards
column11: and cultural relevant understanding. In the 2018-19 school year
column12: \rthe district dedicated five professional development days for certificated staff.  Teachers were offered professional development opportunities on staff\rdevelopment days
column14: and on early release days. A variety of after-school workshops were also offered throughout the school year.\rOne hundred mentors and one hundred and thirty-five participating teachers received ongoing professional development and classroom coaching\rthrough the CUSD Induction program.  In addition
column15: all certificated teachers participated in site-based training and district sponsored training that included:\rcurriculum training
column19: and culturally relevant instructional practices.\r\r\r\rFY 2017-18 Teacher and Administrative Salaries\r\rState Average for\rDistrict CategoryState Average for District\r\rDistricts In Same AmountDistricts In Same\rPercent of District Budget\rAmount Category\r\rCategory\rBeginning Teacher Salary$40

A weekly planning opportunity is provided for teachers to coordinate and plan lessons or units as an entire grade level.\r\rDry Creek’s professional development currently focuses on improving our collective knowledge of curriculum and needed changes in instructional\rdelivery. Our third- through sixth-grade classes participated in the third statewide Smarter Balanced Assessment tests in the spring of 2019. The Dry\rCreek students performed well on the assessments in comparison to all schools in CUSD
column4: and this school year’s fourth- through sixth-grade teachers are\rusing the results to engage students in meaningful conversations about areas of strength and growth. As students become more familiar with this new\rrigorous assessment system
column5: we believe our students will rise to the challenge and demonstrate mastery of the California State Standards.\r\rTeachers new to the profession are sup-ported by a formal mentoring system
column6: which includes release time to observe lessons taught by veteran teachers.\rAll teachers are encouraged to participate in external professional improvement opportunities
column7: such as attendance at conferences and workshops.\r\rThe district focused all professional development activities around five identified needs:  first time best instruction
column10: implementation of the California Content Standards and NGSS Standards
column11: and cultural relevant understanding. In the 2018-19 school year
column12: \rthe district dedicated five professional development days for certificated staff.  Teachers were offered professional development opportunities on staff\rdevelopment days
column14: and on early release days. A variety of after-school workshops were also offered throughout the school year.\rOne hundred mentors and one hundred and thirty-five participating teachers received ongoing professional development and classroom coaching\rthrough the CUSD Induction program.  In addition
column15: all certificated teachers participated in site-based training and district sponsored training that included:\rcurriculum training
column19: and culturally relevant instructional practices.\r\r\r\rFY 2017-18 Teacher and Administrative Salaries\r\rState Average for\rDistrict CategoryState Average for District\r\rDistricts In Same AmountDistricts In Same\rPercent of District Budget\rAmount Category\r\rCategory\rBeginning Teacher Salary$40
column26: see the CDE Certificated Salaries &\rBenefits webpage at www.cde.ca.gov/ds/fd/cs/.\rAverage Principal Salary (ES)$109
